title: The Game Was Rigged—So Why Are We Still Playing?
summary: A systems analysis of how current economic and political structures are designed for extraction, not success. Provides concrete alternatives for breaking each of the 'five hidden rules' that keep people dependent.

Narrative.summary: Understand that current systems are working as designed—for extraction, not human flourishing.

level0: Recognize we're living as 'a society of teenagers'—wanting independence but expecting others to provide
Understand that systems extract value while giving just enough to prevent walking away
level1: See the five hidden rules that maintain dependency: debt, controlled essentials, suppressed wages, information control, political rigging
Recognize current institutional change as opportunity, not just chaos
level2: Frame community projects as 'growing up'—creating systems rather than waiting for them
Understand how parallel systems can influence larger structures
level3: Teach others to recognize extractive vs. generative system design
Lead narrative shifts from individual failure to systemic analysis

Money.summary: Build local trade networks and alternative economic systems that reduce debt dependency.

level0: Recognize money as one form of wealth, not the only form
Practice non-monetary exchanges—bartering, skill trades, gift economy
level1: Participate in or create local currency systems
Build community networks where things can be given freely for collective benefit
level2: Organize community investment pools and cooperative ownership
Create systems that keep wealth circulating locally rather than extracting to distant shareholders
level3: Design comprehensive alternative economic systems for communities
Connect local economic networks to regional resilience systems

Food.summary: Create local food security that breaks dependence on controlled, corporate food systems.

level0: Start any form of food growing—herbs on windowsill, small garden plot
Learn basic food preservation and storage techniques
level1: Join or create community gardens and food sharing networks
Practice seed saving and heritage variety cultivation
level2: Build community food systems that can operate independent of global supply chains
Develop food production that serves local needs rather than profit extraction
level3: Create comprehensive community food security systems
Teach others to build resilient local food networks

Knowledge.summary: Create open knowledge sharing systems that challenge information paywalls and gatekeeping.

level0: Share knowledge freely rather than hoarding professional expertise
Learn economic literacy that schools deliberately don't teach
level1: Organize skill-sharing workshops and community education
Create learning networks that bypass institutional gatekeeping
level2: Develop curricula that teach wealth-building, not just wage-earning
Build educational systems that serve community empowerment
level3: Create comprehensive knowledge-sharing systems that challenge corporate information control
Train others to become knowledge facilitators and community educators

Community.summary: Build parallel community systems that make centralized control structures irrelevant.

level0: Join or create mutual aid groups and community support networks
Practice cooperative problem-solving rather than individual competition
level1: Organize community systems that provide alternatives to corporate services
Build local governance and decision-making processes
level2: Create comprehensive community support systems that reduce dependence on failing institutions
Connect local networks to broader movements for systemic change
level3: Design replicable models for community self-governance and mutual aid
Mentor other communities in building parallel systems
